I wasn't planning to, since it's not needed. Unlike with schemas, individual permissions can be granted on tables.
As discussed on the issue, it's preferable to stay with what's possible in Hive and not diverge from that (Hive cannot grant permissions on schemas, but it can change the owner of a schema).

timeline.bodyText:
Per the SQL spec, the authorization identifier should follow this syntax:
<authorization identifier> ::=
    <role name>
  | <user identifier>

<role name> ::=
  <identifier>

<user identifier> ::=
  <identifier>

principal in this grammar file is defined as:
principal
    : identifier            #unspecifiedPrincipal
    | USER identifier       #userPrincipal
    | ROLE identifier       #rolePrincipal
    ;

Which doesn't fit what the spec describes for this case.
timeline.author: martint
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -42,6 +42,7 @@ statement
         (WITH properties)?                                             #createSchema
     | DROP SCHEMA (IF EXISTS)? qualifiedName (CASCADE | RESTRICT)?     #dropSchema
     | ALTER SCHEMA qualifiedName RENAME TO identifier                  #renameSchema
+    | ALTER SCHEMA qualifiedName SET AUTHORIZATION principal           #setSchemaAuthorization

replies.bodyText: We may want to extend it in the future, but I'd prefer we start conservatively and follow the spec as closely as possible.
replies.author: martint

replies.bodyText:
I thought it was nice that the principal parsing would be the same across GRANT, REVOKE, and SET AUTHORIZATION.
Do we stay closer to the SQL standard or to Presto's existing syntax in similar scenarios?
Also in the standard you cannot set authorization for a user if the user happens to have the same name as a role (and for some database - such as PostgreSQL - where a user and a role are the same thing that's fine).
In order to know whether you set to a user or a role you'd need to check whether such a role does exist.
Happy to change, I just think it's better this way.
replies.author: lhofhansl

replies.bodyText:
Please let me know.
BTW. I looked up the standard system for GRANT and REVOKE and they also use what you cite above:
<authorization identifier>    ::=   <role name> | <user identifier>

<role name>    ::=   <identifier>

<user identifier>    ::=   <identifier>

Given that we already diverged from the SQL standard with GRANT and REVOKE I'd vote for being consistent within Presto.
Also one last point: Unless we force the explicit ROLE syntax, since Presto and Hive do not have pre-defined users, there would be no way to enforce valid roles, when a role is misspelled it would just need to assume that you meant a user.
In the end... Let me know what's the best approach and I'll do that.

As I understand after your change, anyone can change the schema owner. Am I right? If so, then maybe it is better to not to add this security leak to iceberg just yet. WDYT?
replies.author: kokosing

replies.bodyText:
Oh I see what you mean now.
The code here just defers to whatever the referenced HiveMetastore implementation can do.
The real Hive Metastore is one implementation, there's also the filebased metastore, etc. I added the right code to all metastore implementations (and the default is to deny this operation).
The metastore implementations will deny the change if it is not supported (default, unless the metastore implements it), and allow it if is supported, so it should be OK as is!
replies.author: lhofhansl

timeline.message:
Add support for ALTER SCHEMA SET AUTHORIZATION

This adds support for changing the owner of an existing schema
to a new user or role.
